summary: A letter from U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta to attorney Lilly Ann Sanchez regarding the implementation of the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. It outlines a proposed process for selecting attorneys to represent the identified victims, with Judge Davis acting as a mediator/special master, and clarifies that Epstein's proposal for resolving victims' claims falls outside the agreement's terms.

persons.context: Addressee of the letter from U.S. Attorney Acosta; she had written a proposal on behalf of her client, Jeffrey Epstein, regarding the resolution of victims' claims.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused / Client of Lilly Ann Sanchez
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; his attorney proposed a method for resolving victims' claims, which Acosta states falls outside the Non-Prosecution Agreement.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Author of the letter; he responds to Epstein's attorney's proposal and outlines the U.S. Attorney's Office's recommended process for selecting victim representation.

persons.name: Judge Davis
persons.context: Proposed by Acosta to assist pro bono in selecting attorney(s) for the victims and potentially serve as a mediator/special master for any settlements.

connections.description: Sanchez is identified as Epstein's attorney, writing proposals on his behalf regarding the resolution of victim claims.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, is corresponding officially with Epstein's defense attorney regarding the implementation of the Non-Prosecution Agreement.
Acosta proposes that Judge Davis could mediate settlements between Epstein and the victims, with Epstein potentially paying Davis's fees if mediation proceeds.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Reference to a previously signed Non-Prosecution Agreement between Jeffrey Epstein and the United States government.

events.title: Acosta's Response to Epstein's Proposal
events.description: U.S. Attorney Acosta sends a letter rejecting Epstein's attorney's proposal for resolving victim claims as falling outside the Non-Prosecution Agreement and outlining an alternative process.

keyFacts: U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta formally states that a proposal from Jeffrey Epstein's attorney for resolving victims' claims 'does not believe that your proposal falls within the terms of the Non-Prosecution Agreement'.
The U.S. Attorney's Office proposes that Judge Davis assist pro bono in selecting attorney(s) to represent the identified victims, with the victims free to choose their own counsel if desired.
The letter reveals a planned structure where, if victims agree, Judge Davis could serve as a mediator/special master for out-of-court settlements, with Epstein paying Davis's fees at that point.
The correspondence shows direct, high-level DOJ involvement (the U.S. Attorney) in managing the post-agreement process for victim representation and potential settlement.
